brand_info.name: Louis Vuitton
brand_info.category: Luxury fashion house / leather goods, ready-to-wear, accessories, jewelry, watches, perfumes
brand_info.positioning: A Parisian luxury Maison rooted in trunk-making and the art of travel, defined by exceptional craftsmanship, iconic codes (Monogram and Damier), and a global lifestyle universe spanning leather goods, fashion, and culture.
brand_info.vision: To continuously expand the Maison's heritage of travel, craftsmanship, and creative innovation into a complete luxury lifestyle, creating enduring icons that remain relevant across generations.
brand_info.mission: To create and craft exceptional products and experiences grounded in savoir-faire, innovation, and the art of travel, elevating everyday life through design, quality, and cultural dialogue.
brand_info.origin_story: Founded in 1854 in Paris by Louis Vuitton, who opened his first store at 4 Rue Neuve-des-Capucines near Place Vendome after years apprenticing as a master trunk-maker and packer. The Maison innovated travel trunks for a world on the move and built its artisanal heart in Asnieres-sur-Seine, where craftsmanship and innovation continue to be passed down.

brand_values.brand_promise: Every Louis Vuitton creation delivers unmistakable Maison codes with uncompromising craftsmanship and a sense of journey, making luxury feel both iconic and lived-in.
differentiators: Heritage in trunk-making and travel innovation since 1854, with atelier culture anchored in Asnieres-sur-Seine
Iconic, globally recognized signature canvases and codes (Monogram, Damier) applied across categories
A lifestyle approach that merges fashion, travel, and cultural collaborations into a cohesive universe
non_negotiables: No dilution of craftsmanship, materials, or finishing quality
No off-brand logo treatments or altered typography for the Louis Vuitton wordmark
No generic stock-look visuals that erase the Maison's travel and icon-making identity

demographics.income_level: Affluent to ultra-affluent; luxury aspirational segments for entry categories

psychographics.lifestyle: Globally mobile, culture-forward individuals who value icons, craftsmanship, and experiences. They travel for work and pleasure, collect objects with heritage, and engage with fashion as a lifestyle signal.
psychographics.behavior: Purchases are driven by signature codes, craftsmanship credibility, and campaign storytelling. High willingness to invest in hero leather goods, travel pieces, and seasonal fashion statements that still feel anchored in the Maison universe.

tone_of_voice.communication_style: Minimal copy, strong visual storytelling; declarative and assured rather than explanatory.
preferred_structures: Short, title-like phrases that suggest travel, craftsmanship, and modern culture
Proper-noun emphasis (Maison, heritage, atelier) with restrained messaging
avoid: Overly technical product copy in ads
Excessively playful slang that undercuts luxury authority
tone_of_voice.emotional_temperature: Cool confidence with cinematic warmth; aspirational but not loud.
tone_dos: Let images carry meaning; keep text sparse
Use cultural and journey cues to elevate product desire

logo.primary_logo: LOUIS VUITTON wordmark in uppercase with wide tracking, typically white on image or black on light backgrounds; the LV monogram used as a product code and emblem.
logo.usage_rules: Keep the wordmark perfectly horizontal, unwarped, high-contrast, and clean. Prefer centered placement across the frame or lower third with generous breathing room.
logo.lockup_behavior: Wordmark often appears alone without additional copy; it can overlay the subject but must remain highly legible.
logo.safe_area: Maintain clear space around the wordmark equal to at least the height of the letter 'O' to avoid visual crowding.

color_system.color_usage_rules: Logo and typography are strictly monochrome. Image palettes oscillate between warm sunlit neutrals (sand, beige, honey, tobacco leather) and cool cinematic blues/greens, with occasional saturated accents (deep red) used as fashion or scenography anchors.

typography.primary_font: Custom Louis Vuitton wordmark (uppercase, wide letterspacing)
typography.secondary_font: Clean modern sans-serif for functional UI (website, captions) when needed

weights.headlines: Regular to medium with wide tracking

hierarchy: H1 - LOUIS VUITTON wordmark, centered, dominant
H2 - Minimal supporting line (rare), small, high-contrast
Body - Used sparingly; preference for near-zero copy

layout_principles.grid_system: Center-weighted editorial composition with strong negative space and horizon lines; asymmetric balance via subject placement
layout_principles.white_space_ratio: High; backgrounds often simplified by shallow detail or atmospheric haze
layout_principles.cta_placement: Usually absent in campaign key visuals; when present, small and secondary
layout_principles.alignment: Wordmark commonly centered horizontally across mid-frame or lower third

style.camera_feel: High-end fashion cinema stills: narrative moments, poised subjects, and objects as travel companions. Frames feel like a chapter from a journey rather than a studio product shot.
style.pose_guidelines: Relaxed but deliberate: seated, leaning, walking, or paused mid-journey. Faces are often turned away or in profile, suggesting movement and introspection rather than direct engagement.
style.casting_attitude: Global, diverse casting with confident composure. Expression ranges from calm to contemplative; attitude is self-possessed, never performative.

technical.lighting: Naturalistic cinematic lighting: golden-hour sun, soft overcast diffusion, or controlled studio softness with atmospheric haze; occasional dramatic backlight silhouettes.
technical.contrast: Medium to high depending on scene; silhouettes and hard sun are used for graphic impact while preserving luxury texture.
technical.grain: Low to moderate; occasional filmic texture and haze for mood.
technical.depth_of_field: Moderate to shallow, with backgrounds softened to keep the subject and product readable.
technical.color_grading: Warm neutrals and honeyed highlights for travel scenes; muted greens/teals for studio moods; overall saturation controlled with selective accent color emphasis.

preferred_locations: Transit and travel environments (trains, stations, boats, automobiles)
Minimalist architectural corridors and sculptural spaces
Studio vignettes featuring trunks and travel objects as set design
contexts: Travel as narrative: subjects in motion or between places, with luggage as an extension of identity
Icon objects staged as companions: bags and trunks integrated into the scene, not isolated
Atmospheric fashion tableaux: horizon lines, open skies, or controlled color fields that frame the subject

model_casting.diversity: High; global representation across skin tones and features
model_casting.attitude: Poised confidence, quiet charisma, and a sense of being mid-journey

product_presentation.hero_visibility: Product is clearly visible and readable, either held naturally or staged prominently within the scene (often with trunks as set pieces).
product_presentation.styling_approach: Elevated fashion silhouettes with tactile materials; styling supports narrative and brand codes rather than minimalism. Accessories and bags are central and intentional.
avoid: Overcrowded props unrelated to travel or Maison codes
Cheap-looking textures or overly glossy artificial finishes

motion_rules.pacing: Measured, cinematic pacing; implied movement through posture and environment rather than action blur.
motion_rules.transitions: Soft cuts and cinematic continuity; atmosphere and location changes feel like a journey chapter.

visual_dos: Use the wordmark as the singular graphic element, large and clean
Build scenes around travel, movement, and iconic objects (bags, trunks)
Keep backgrounds atmospheric and simplified for brand legibility
Prioritize material realism: leather, canvas, metal hardware must read premium
visual_donts: Do not add extra typography blocks, badges, or promotional stickers
Do not distort the wordmark or reduce contrast
Do not use flat stock-photo lighting or generic lifestyle scenes without travel codes
Do not obscure the hero product with hands, cropping, or clutter
copy_dos: Keep copy minimal and elevated; let narrative come from image
copy_donts: No pricing, discounts, or aggressive imperative CTAs

must_remain: LOUIS VUITTON wordmark integrity: uppercase, tracking, and clean rendering
Maison codes and craftsmanship credibility (premium materials, accurate hardware, precise construction)
Travel and icon-making narrative (objects as companions, not mere props)
can_evolve: Casting, cultural references, and contemporary styling provided the world remains luxurious and coherent
Location palette shifts (cool modernism vs warm travel) while preserving the cinematic language
Product category focus (fashion, leather goods, beauty) while keeping the same brand staging logic
test_zone: High-concept scenography and bold color fields as long as the product and wordmark remain dominant
New formats (social, vertical video) using the same minimal brand overlay and cinematic photography rules

materials: Polished stone, warm wood, and brushed metal accents
Leather and canvas textures as tactile cues
interactive_elements: Personalization stations and travel service touchpoints
Quiet digital storytelling screens for heritage and craft
retail.soundscape: Subtle ambient music; calm, curated atmosphere with an art-gallery sensibility

digital.tone_adjustment: On website and socials, visuals stay dominant; copy is sparse and product-led. Social formats keep the wordmark presence strong and the narrative travel cue intact.

platform_behavior.Instagram: Cinematic frames, strong wordmark overlays in key visuals, travel and icon storytelling
platform_behavior.Website: Full-bleed imagery, minimal copy, editorial navigation to categories and heritage stories
platform_behavior.Newsletter: Hero image first, minimal lines of copy, product icons emphasized

print.paper: High-quality matte or semi-matte stock with rich blacks and controlled highlights
print.cover_rules: Full-bleed photography with large centered wordmark; minimal additional text

logo_misuse_examples: Warping, stretching, or applying effects to the LOUIS VUITTON wordmark
Placing the wordmark on low-contrast backgrounds that reduce legibility
Adding extra decorative typography, badges, or CTA blocks that compete with the wordmark
